Award.AwardTitle: From Individuals to Communities: Consequences of Ontogenetic Functional Diversity for Community Structure and Functioning
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central challenge in community ecology is to understand the connection between biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems. The traditional approach in community ecology and particular in food web theory is based on the premise that predictions can be made by treating a species as a homogenous entity. However, no population is truly homogenous and individuals within a species often vary considerably in their ecological function. By far the largest source of this functional variation between individuals stems from differences in size and developmental stage. Indeed, the functional variation across developmental stages within a species often exceeds the variation across species. The unresolved question is how this functional variation within species affects the structure and functioning of natural ecosystems. This question will be answered using a combination of field experiments manipulating the stage-structure in predatory invertebrates in natural pond communities, and development of a new theoretical framework that accounts for functional variation across developmental stages. Together these studies will provide first insight into how the ecological variation across developmental stages within species may alter the structure, dynamics, and functioning of entire ecosystems.
Human activities are fundamentally changing ecological systems and natural populations. Our ability to predict how such changes will affect the functioning of ecosystems will critically depend on our understanding of the detailed mechanisms that connect intraspecific diversity to ecosystem functions. The study will permit a new detailed understanding of the mechanisms that determine how individuals scale up to affect entire communities and their functioning. The obtained results will advance our conceptual understanding of whether and what details need to be included in a general predictive framework for community dynamics and ecosystem processes and guide the development of conservation and harvest strategies to assure that vital ecosystem functions are not lost in the future. It will also provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including underrepresented groups in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Linking the structure of communities to ecosystem functioning has been a perennial challenge in ecology. Studies on ecosystem function are traditionally focused on changes in species composition. However, this species-centric approach neglects the often dramatic changes in the ecology of organisms during their development, thereby limiting our ability to link the structure of populations and communities to the functioning of natural ecosystems. In this project, we used a combination of experiments and mathematical models to demonstrate that different developmental stages can differ dramatically in their ecological role. Results demonstrate that the impact of organisms on community structure and ecosystem processes often differ more among developmental stages within a species than between species, contrary to current assumptions. One important implication is that changes in the demography of populations can strongly alter the functional composition of communities and change ecosystem processes long before any species are extirpated from communities. Furthermore, results also demonstrate that we need to account for changes in ecological interactions during the development of organisms to correctly predict the extinction risk of species and stability of entire ecosystems. Together, these results demonstrate that natural ecosystems are more senstitive to disturbances than previously thought, and emphasize the importance of incorporating variation within species into community ecology, conservation biology, and strategies for managing natural ecosystems.

Broader Impacts

Our study demonstrates that ability to predict how natural and anthropogenic changes will affect the functioning of ecosystems critically depends on our understanding of the detailed mechanisms that connect intraspecific diversity to ecosystem functions. The obtained results provide a novel general predictive framework for community dynamics and ecosystem processes which will help to guide the development of conservation and harvest strategies (e.g. in fisheries) to assure that vital ecosystem functions are not lost in the future.  The results were broadly distributed by publishing more than 15 papers in scientific peer reviewed journals and through communication with local federal and state agencies (e.g. USDA, USGS, and National Forrest Service). The project also provided training opportunities for three PhD and 31 undergraduate students, including 11 students from underrepresented groups in science. It also engaged in K12 outreach activities, including training of high school students and participation in programs to advance professional development of high school teachers.
